title: Cost of barristers, advocates and agency workers in SEND tribunals

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please could you provide the following information:
In the last two years (January 1, 2022 - December 31, 2023), for SEND tribunal hearings and tribunals related to disabled children, for children in the local authority area:
- How much has SCC spent annually on barristers' fees?
-  How much has SCC spent annually on agency solicitors' fees?
-  How much has SCC spent annually on advocates fees?
Yours faithfully,
Alastair Ulke

Dear Alistair Ulke
Thank you for your request for an internal review relating to cost of
barristers, advocates, and agency workers in SEND tribunals, which we
received on 01/07/2024. This arose because of our failure to respond to
your original request. This response is in two parts. Firstly, we respond
to your request. Secondly, we address your complaint.
Cost of barristers, advocates, and agency workers in SEND tribunals
Here is the information about the spend annually on agency solicitors’
fees for SEND tribunal hearings.
┌─────────────┬───────────────────────┐
│Hearing Year │Charges │
├─────────────┼───────────────────────┤
│2022 │£17,447.97 │
├─────────────┼───────────────────────┤
│2023 │£86,890.35 │
├─────────────┼───────────────────────┤
│Grand Total │£104,338.32 │
└─────────────┴───────────────────────┘
The difference between the two figures is the in-house legal spend.
Year SCC spent annually on Tribunal hearings.
2022 - £44,455.55
2023 - £138,638.86
We do not hold information on the spend on barristers’ fees or advocates’
fees.
Complaint
We uphold your complaint about our failure to respond to the legal
deadlines for this request. Your request was made on 3 April 2024, we
acknowledged it on 5 April 2024, with a deadline of 1 May 2024. On 3 June
2024 you chased the response and on 1 July 2024 formally complained. We
acknowledged this request on 4 July 2024 with a deadline of 30 July 2024.
On 8 August and 9 September 2024 you chased our response. On 23 September
2024 the Information Commissioner asked that we respond by 7 October 2024.
We have missed three deadlines to respond.
We have breached both Section 10 of the Act and the Code of Practice under
Section 45 regarding the timeliness of internal reviews. We have had the
information since 1 May 2024 but thought there was a question regarding
its provenance. We subsequently overlooked our response. Your subsequent
chasers were all flagged for action.
We sincerely apologise for the delays to our response, and that you had to
complain to the Information Commissioner. We recognise that as a
journalist there is a particular public interest in our response, because
of your role in informing the public. We handle 2000 requests per year,
and have a busy Inbox. We realise that is no defence to your legal rights.
We can only undertake to ensure this does not happen again.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[2]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind regards
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
